App description:
The Thrill of the Fight is a down-to-earth VR boxing game focused on authenticity. Enter a virtual gym and battle a series of unique challengers with their own styles and techniques. Use timing and skill to land the knockout blow. Evade swings, land jabs, and block punches to become the king of the ring!

Room scale is required with a minimum supported play area size of 6.5ft by 6.5ft (2m by 2m). Please ensure your Guardian boundaries are set up properly for room scale and that you are willing to move and punch anywhere within and around the play area you have defined.

Developer ResponseJul 16 at 7:37 AM

Thanks for your honest review. You and the opponent don't have health bars, and you're not really "inflicting" the points of damage you see on the boxing dummy. Instead, each of your hits is looked at individually to see what effect it had. You do wear the opponent down a bit with each hit to make them easier to hurt with future hits, and as you found you can play by throwing endless haymakers and hoping to completely wear them down before you exhaust yourself (and some people genuinely love to play that way), but you aren't expected to. Try taking fewer swings (aim for 30 to 50 landed per 3 minute round) and focusing on moving around your play area and looking for openings in your opponent's defense to throw purposeful, full-body, precisely-aimed shots at those weak areas. The higher settings you mention are generally intended for exercise or unfair challenge, which is why they're called Endurance and Outclassed instead of "Hard" and "Very Hard", and those two do require you to wear your opponent down before you can hurt them. Normal mode is the one the game is balanced around, and you can KO your opponent with your first swing if you manage to land the perfect shot to the side of the chin (which is extremely hard to pull off). Note that the side of the chin is the most devastating spot to hit on the opponent's head, and there is no weak spot for the ribs - just the liver on the right side of the body. Also while you're punch strength is important, you don't need to swing as hard as you can, and the game works better if you don't. Just swing at a comfortable level of effort, try to create openings, and aim for those weak areas. The more you move around and play the part of a real boxer, the more enjoyable the game should be.

Update:

I still play this game religiously. I expected that. But what I didn't expect is that it's actually making me a better boxer. It still doesn't replace actual sparring and bag work. But it 1000% replaces shadow boxing.

My upper back and shoulders are actually bigger than they've ever been. Throwing with 100% power is not easy without something to actually impact. Especially if you have a virtual opponent just waiting for you to over commit and throw yourself off balance.

Also, since the VR goggles handicap my peripheral vision, it forces me to up my ringmanship game.

Finally, I'm also impressed with the effectiveness of feinting. Which I imagine it's a really tough thing to get right. After I had progressed though the difficulty levels, opponents started beating me to the punch pretty often near the end of my sessions when I was wiped out. At times, almost like they were in my head.

But I started to add in the feints that I had previously abandoned and, what do you know, it worked! I was getting countered a lot less and finding more openings. Buying myself a bit of breathing room at the same time. Just like happens to me in real sparring. Feint early and often, kids. Before it becomes necessary. Developer ResponseApr 24 at 8:08 AM

Thanks for the review! I think that for you as a boxer, looking at the game like shadowboxing against a visual target is the right approach, and I'm glad you're enjoying it. I just wanted to mention that 1) I didn't design the game around requiring people to need to throw as hard as they can and 2) the AI is much easier to hit than what you likely expect from a real opponent, so the damage system focuses more on hitting weak areas on the opponent instead of just hitting hard and often, and the weak areas are harder to hit than they would be in real life (which slightly helps make up for the AI being easier to hit). This is likely why your 20 hit combos don't seem to hurt the opponent as much as you feel like they should compared to real life. Also, the game adjusts based on your strength by default, and if you feel it's making you too weak, you can go into the Settings menu, turn off "Automatic Force Adjustment", and use the multipliers to adjust your strength however you want - but be warned that "1x" doesn't mean "real-world" or anything like that, so put the sliders where they feel best and not just at 1x. There is a little bit of a power bonus for lunges or extreme body rotation, but it's more there as a nod to players that are looking for something like that, and I've intentionally kept it's effect very minor just because I don't have a good way to read out how much body mass you're actually transferring into your swings. The real reason the AI feels stronger than you is because they throw fewer, harder punches aimed at your weak areas, but on Normal (and apart from Duke and Moneymaker) they can't hit any harder than you can and the lean/rotation bonus doesn't really factor into it.

Developer ResponseJun 23 at 6:24 AM

Thanks for the review and the suggestions. TotF is "roomscale" only and uses your play area as a miniature boxing ring that you're meant to physically move around in, which is why I list a minimum required play area size on the store page. Oculus intends that you only draw your boundaries so that there are no real objects inside for you to hit, and the game expects that you've set your boundaries up as Oculus instructs. On Quest, when a game wants to use the actual play area size, the Quest has to be in a special mode that also disables the functionality of the recenter button. TotF never even knows you try to recenter. It's like this so that there's not a mismatch between the in-game play area and your real world play area. In TotF, you can face a direction of your play area and set it to be the new "front" side by holding down the menu button (like the recenter button, but on the other controller) for two seconds.

Developer ResponseMay 25 at 12:12 PM

Thanks for your honest review. I do want to mention that while the game does care about the exact relative strength of your hits, it's designed so that players are not required to have to swing with any specific level of strength in order to play. As part of that, the damage system is focused on landing purposeful, accurate strikes to the opponent's weak areas if you want to take them down. These are intentionally a bit harder to hit than they would be in real life, but that's because AI is much easier to hit than a real human would be. On Normal mode, the AI can't hit any harder than you can (except for Duke and Moneymaker who do hit harder and are harder to hurt), so anything the AI does to you, you can do right back to them if you're aiming for those weak points and really picking your punches and following up properly. Endurance and Outclassed modes are special challenge modes that intentionally make it very hard to hurt the opponent though (which is why they're named the way they are) so avoid those modes unless you specifically want to have to work yourself like crazy to win. Cranking the multiplier all the way up should still lead to extremely easy knockdowns on Normal from combos, but it has a limit to how hard it can make your hardest hits land for, so just doing that alone won't make you be able to down your opponent in one hit without aiming for the weak areas. If you're looking for that, you'll need to use the Custom menu to reduce their Toughness.

Best VR boxing game on Oculus Quest

The Thrill of the Fight on the Oculus Quest, the ultimate version of the game! Since the Oculus Quest ergonomics are terrible, I can now feel like my face has been punched several times after wearing the Quest for only 20+ minutes, just like the real experience! So immersive!

Jokes aside, this game is the best VR boxing simulation on the market as of time of this review. If you are interested in boxing, don't think twice and buy this. The single developer of the game, Ian Fitz, is also awesome. He answers questions/comments people have on his game all over the internet. IMO, he is the example of a game developer to follow. AAA game studios, watch and learn. This is how its done.

Game mechanics:
You can throw all types of punches and the game registers what type of punch you did: cross, jab, hook, uppercut. The faster you throw your fists at the opponent, the more damage you do to the opponent. The game also rewards accurate punches with more damage on some of the critical areas of the body. To learn where those areas are, you can train with the dummy. The game auto-adjusts to your own speed by using a force multiplier, so you don't need to be an expert boxer to enjoy the game. After a round of fighting, the next round will be adjusted to your max speed. To knock an opponent, you need to chain multiple strong hits in a short period of time. Those strong hits display a yellow or red marquer on the opponent where you hit them. Blue markers show a weak hit. There is also a notion of cumulative damage, which enable you to knock opponents easier in the later rounds (kind of emulating that the opponent is tired). There is no stamina mechanic like in Creed. The stamina of your fighter is your stamina. If you are tired and can't punch anymore, that's when you will lose. You need to learn to pace yourself and be precise with your punches.

If you want to get back in shape, or just have a tremendous amount of fun while shadow boxing, buy this now! Good job Ian!

Developer ResponseMay 30 at 8:31 AM

Thanks for your honest review. I have a few tips that might help. First, while knockdowns play a very big role, they're not the primary goal, and it's important that you don't focus on trying too hard to down the opponent at the expense of everything else. As you mentioned, you are physically tiring yourself with each punch you throw, so you want to make sure you're landing effective punches to make the most of the real-world energy you're expending. You and the opponent don't have health bars that you're chipping away at with each punch. Instead, each punch is looked at for the effectiveness it had, and you and the opponent are both able to shrug off less effective punches with little permanent effect. This means that you really need to be purposeful with the punches you're throwing and making sure they're solidly landing to locations that will cause pain or injury to your opponent. These strike zones are marked on the boxing dummy, and you can see how well you're hitting them by looking at the "Weak Point Bonus" stat on the info panel. Note that they are directional, most of them need to be hit from the side, and the side of the chin is an especially effective target. They're also very hard to hit and take a bit of practice to master, but you're not expected to be nailing them with every swing you throw. Just swing in that general area whenever you can, and you'll occasionally make good connections. The colored splash when you land a hit roughly conveys how effective your punches are. The splashes blend from blue to yellow to red. Solid blue hits don't do much at all and solid red hits are very devastating. When you do land a good hit, you'll hear the opponent grunt and their face will look a bit stunned. When that happens, you'll want to quickly try to follow up with more swings to secure a knockdown. Don't panic, because you still need to be landing high quality shots, and if you get too focused on downing the opponent, it's easy to not realize they've recovered and are back in fighting shape. While you're trying to do all this to the opponent, they're trying to do the same to you, so keep your guard up (don't try to block on reaction) and try to be evasive. Make sure to move around your playspace if you can, and take advantage of staying out of range when you need to. Finally, the game does care about how hard you're swinging, but you don't need to swing very hard to play the game - in fact, swinging as hard as you possibly can just doesn't work very well. The game adjusts your range of strength based on how hard it think you can hit (that's what the multiplier is), so just try to swing comfortably. If you you find you're swinging harder sometimes during a fight and the game is adjusting to it when you don't want it to, you can go to the bottom of the Settings menu, turn off the "Automatic Force Adjustment" feature, and manually adjust your multiplier. Before you do that, I'd suggest playing a full match against the sparring partner while swinging comfortably, so that your multiplier is adjusted to a comfortable number by default when you turn the automatic adjustment off.

Developer ResponseMar 1 at 9:39 AM

Thanks for your review! You and the opponent don't have any sort of "health bar" mechanic that determines whether you get knocked down or not, so in general there's really no direct concept of how close you are to being knocked down. Instead, each punch landed is looked at individually to see what effect it had. You and the AI score knockdowns by either landing a single devastating punch that's enough to floor the opponent or by rocking the opponent with a hard hit and stumbling them with hard follow-ups. The more damaging the hit was that put the opponent on the floor, the longer the opponent will stay down. Wearing the opponent down with non-knockdown hits will also make it easier to hurt the opponent with your future hits (by a very small amount that's only becomes noticeable towards the end of the fight) and will keep them on the floor longer when they get knocked down. Knockdowns from rocking and stumbling aren't likely to keep an opponent down for the count even if you have worn them down, and you really need to nail one of the weak areas (marked on the dummy) to stand much of a chance at a one-hit knockdown that keeps the opponent down for long. You get an increasing permanent vignette effect on your screen that shows how "worn down" you are, but if you're not taking a lot of hits you might not ever notice it. Generally you'll be taken down by good hits that nail one of your weak areas or by hard hits that noticeably rock you first (grayscale screen effect) before you drop to a follow-up. If the AI is able to put you down for the count, it's because they nailed you with an absolutely perfect shot, and that should be extremely rare on Normal mode (which is the "balanced" mode). The other modes increase the AI's punching power and lets them drop you more easily with single hits (in addition to letting them shrug off your hits better and boosting other stats) and are intentionally meant to feel one-sided. Duke and Moneymaker also hit a little harder (and can shrug off hits better) than the rest of the roster, so it's easier for them to do, too.

Developer ResponseApr 17 at 4:26 PM

Thanks so much for reconsidering your review. You've shared some valuable info in this post, and I think I can help get things working well for you. First, though, please absolutely make sure the boundaries you've drawn only include areas you're willing to move and punch within and that you don't have them right up against the edge of a wall or other obstacle. It doesn't have to be a huge gap, but you do want to leave a little margin of error in case the Quest didn't put the boundary exactly where you thought you drew it. If you're in roomscale mode and your boundaries are clear, you should be all set as far as the opponent staying within your free space. The game itself is actually designed around 2m by 1.5m of space as a minimum (up to 4m by 4m maximum), but I list 2m by 2m on the Quest because that's what Oculus lists as their minimum roomscale size on Quest. The way the Quest picks its "forward" direction is a little mysterious to me, but I have a couple of ways in the game that you can change it. First, if you want to pick a completely new forward direction for the game to use, hold down the menu button for a couple of seconds - i.e., the button that's like the normal recenter button, but on the other controller. I use that one because the Quest handles recenter requests itself instead of passing the request on to the game, and it doesn't do anything for games that are in roomscale mode (the Rift lets the game handle the recenter request even when in roomscale mode, and that version of TotF uses the normal recenter button to pick a new forward direction, as you'd expect). Doing this will take whatever edge of your play area (the red rectangle on the floor) that you're looking at and make it the new "front" side. The next thing you can do is go into the in-game Settings menu and change the "In-Match Turn Direction" setting. That makes your forward direction different when you're in a match compared to when you're not in one. You can use that to, for example, make the menu screen be 3m side-to-side while having the matches be 3m front-to-back, which is probably what I'd recommend for the shape of the play area you have. Please feel free to email me at fyiandev@gmail.com, and I'll be happy to help if you have any questions about getting these configured. Thanks!

Thanks for your review! Regarding the controller drifting off, it might be an issue where fast movements cause the spring in the battery compartment to compress, causing the battery to lose contact on the other end. I've seen users fix this by using a conductive shim, putting in a stiffer spring, putting shelf liner in the battery compartment, and putting a couple tiny rubber bands around the battery. Developer ResponseMay 9 at 4:53 PM

Thanks for the review. Some quick advice: If you're swinging really hard to try to take him down, try swinging less hard. While the relative strength of your swings does matter, the game is more about accurately aiming at the weak areas marked on the boxing dummy. The game adjusts to your strength by default, so if you swing comfortably it will work as expected. If you swing too hard, though, the game will just adjust around that, and it will be harder to keep up with. You can also turn this off (at the bottom of the Settings menu) if you don't want it to automatically adjust. Focus on making every punch count, and if you don't have a good opening then don't try to throw. Remember to move around your play area to keep your distance when needed. Do your best to avoid his swings, and if you land a good hit on him make sure to follow up while aiming for those weak areas. Make sure not to get too focused while you're beating on him, and back off before he recovers. As the champion, he represents the best of every opponent you've fought and is meant to be a significant challenge.

Thrilling but lacking

TL;DR Worth the price for the fights and the basic workout, but the lack of guided training or instruction leaves the game feeling half baked.

I enjoying playing "Thrill Of The Fight". It offers a great simulation of a boxing match and I find the fights to indeed be thrilling. However, they can become frustrating due to lack of guided training or instruction. There is a menu card on the main screen that gives some tips, but not much else. You have to figure things out on your own and train yourself.

The game whats you to focus on timing and hitting specific points of impact to maximize the effect of your punches, like in real boxing, but never really gives you instruction on how to do that or feedback of how you may be doing it right or wrong.

The most you get is a training dummy with the correct impact points that you can train on and a window to the side that displays hit data but you kinda have to figure it out on your own. To be fair, there may have been a brief explanation window when you first play explaining this concept, but I can't find a way to bring it back and reread it. They are also heavy bag, speed bag, and focus ball training modes but unless you already know how to use them your not going to get any help from the game.

Also there is a man that stands behind you while training, or ringside when fighting, silently watching and judging but offering little else. I think he is either meant to be your trainer or a perv that just likes to hang out at the local gym watching people. You can punch him though, so thats something.

In the end I would recommend the game for the exercise and the challenge of the fights, as its not too expensive and fun, but don't look to the game to help you improve in your bouts. You'll have to look elsewhere for instruction.

Developer ResponseFeb 19 at 8:02 AM

Thanks for your review. So far when players have reached out to me about this problem and we look into it together, what has been happening is that their fist has been passing behind the opponent's head. There's some sort of predictive behavior or something like that with Oculus's tracking system that causes fast hooks to drift outward. The faster your hook, the farther out the tracking drifts, as if your arm is longer than it should be. This can result in you being able to hit the opponent from farther away than you should be able to, and it can cause your fist to reach past the back of their head causing you to miss. The best way to address this is to punch a little slower. Boxing style hooks thrown by pros are in the 14m/s range, so if you're seeing much higher speeds than that on the heavy bag then try throwing your hook more by rotating your body with a locked arm and less by planting your body and whipping your arm. There's also an in-game setting that can help prevent the behind-the-head drift issue (called "Drift Protection"), but if you turn that on then you absolutely need to be sure that your floor height is calibrated correctly, as the setting limits the distance away from you the glove can go based on your height.

Developer ResponseMay 26 at 7:21 AM

As mentioned in the game's description, you MUST have 6.5ft by 6.5ft (2m by 2m) of real-world space to play in, and your Guardian boundaries must be set up in room scale mode around this free space. Your Guardian boundaries should not be drawn anywhere you can't move and punch into. This requirement is because you're expected to physically move around your play area like it's a miniature boxing ring, and there is no joystick movement. The game uses a special mode on Quest called "stage mode" that allows the game to map to your Guardian boundary play area size. When a game on Quest is in "stage mode", the Quest's recenter button stops doing anything and the Quest doesn't notify the game that the user is trying to recenter, so TotF doesn't know and can't know you're holding the recenter button. Even if it was able to, since the game is mapped to your play area size and location, the game still wouldn't shift to recenter around you because that would make the in-game play area no longer line up properly with your real-world play area. On Rift, I do respond to the recenter button by changing the side of your play area that you're facing to be the new front side. On Quest, I've had to move that functionality to holding down the menu button on the other controller, since I can't detect when players are trying to recenter. TotF was tweaked specifically for Quest, and then those changes were actually ported back to the other platforms that the game is on.

Hey, I'd love to help with the re-centering with some quick tips, if I can. The red rectangle on the floor is what the Quest system software says is your "play area". I believe it's calculated as the largest rectangle that will fit inside your boundaries, but you don't have any more specific control over the size or shape of it than that. TotF is "room scale" only and the fighting always takes place within that play area reported by the Quest. If you want to change your play area, you'll need to redraw your boundaries. Recentering doesn't do anything because there's no point of reference to center by in room scale mode (and in fact, when a game is in room scale mode on the Quest - they call it "stage" mode - the recenter request isn't even passed to the game by the Quest system software).

Developer ResponseDec 26 at 7:13 AM

Hey, I'd like to help out with this if possible. I've had a few reports of people saying their right hand is flying off, but so far all of those people have been right-handed and have kept their right hand in the rear and put their left hand out as their lead hand. Do you happen to be left handed and are keeping your left hand in back? If so, what might be happening is that the Quest cameras may be losing track of your rear hand when you're guarding. Another issue that's been reported is that very fast punches that comes to a sudden stop (like a lightning fast jab or cross) can cause the spring in the battery terminal to compress, causing the battery to lose contact with the other terminal and blinking off power to the controller for a moment. This usually results in the controller either freezing in air where the power dropped out or flying off in the direction the punch was headed until it reconnects. Users have fixed this before by inserting a conductive shim to wedge the battery in tighter, replacing the battery spring with a stiffer one, or lining the battery compartment with sticky shelf liner to hold the battery in place. I've also heard some people say that fast, wide, looping hooks will cause a tracking issue as well. I'm not sure exactly what it is about that style of punch that's causing the issue, but I think it may be that a really wide swing will cause the controller to spend too much time out of the sight of the tracking cameras while you're "loading up" and then the high force of the swing causes the controller to fly off in a direction before the cameras can reacquire tracking. You can go to the in-game Settings menu and turn on the controller outline option if you want to verify this is a tracking issue. Those controller outlines are positioned directly by the tracking issue, so if they're displaying a problem then it's a problem with where the Quest thinks the controllers are. Developer ResponseOct 27 at 6:48 AM

Thanks for your review! Your opponent doesn't really have "health" per se. You can wear them down over time to make them easier to knock down, but they don't have a hidden health bar that you're chipping away at with each punch until they fall down or anything like that. Instead, each punch you land is looked at to see what effect it had on the opponent. You can get a knockout with your first punch if you land your best swing perfectly to the side of their chin or you could land a million light hits in a round and not affect the opponent at all. Make sure that if you get a yellow or red hit, hear them grunt, and see them with a dazed look on their face that you try to follow up to secure a knockdown before they recover (but don't overexpose or overtire yourself in the process if it's just not happening). Their dizzy/confused face is the same thing as when you get the black-and-white screen effect after you take a hard hit. Also, if you feel like you should be hitting harder than the game is allowing you to, then you might want to go to the very last option in the in-game Settings menu, turn off "Automatic Force Adjustment" and (slowly) increase the sliders until your punch strength feels like what you want it to. I hope that info helps!

Developer ResponseNov 4 at 6:14 PM

Thanks for your review. I appreciate that you still gave 3 stars despite the negative experience you had with it. You're probably a bit confused as to how others are managing to enjoy the game despite the experience you had, and I thought I'd try to provide a little bit of an explanation even if it doesn't change the way you personally feel about the game. TotF is meant to be more of a real-world inspired experience rather than an arcadey action game. There are no life bars because there are no life bars in actual real-world boxing. In fact, mechanically in TotF there's no behind-the-scenes life bar to show even if you wanted to see it because the damage system doesn't work like that. Instead, each hit you land is looked at individually to see how hard it landed, where it hit, and from what direction to determine what effect it had on the opponent. Many hits will just put the opponent on the defensive but won't really hurt them. Some may hurt them and eventually cause them to get worn down, but otherwise won't be much of an immediate threat. Some will dizzy them, which you can see from their reaction to the hit and through their facial expression, and you can attempt to follow up before they recover to secure a knockdown. Some can knock them down outright in a single hit if landed in the right way and to the right place. You're meant to use real boxing punching form, real boxing defense, and move around your real-world play area as if it were a miniature boxing ring as if you were doing virtual interactive shadowboxing. You need to play the part a bit, and you get out of it what you put in. Apparently many people are attracted to that more grounded and real-world inspired form of gameplay, and that's what sets TotF apart from the other boxing games that are available. Despite the boxing theme shared by the games, TotF is really nothing like Creed in the same way that Creed is really nothing like Knockout League. If you go into one of those three games expecting the gameplay from one of the others, you're going to be confused and disappointed. Aside from that, there are other shortcomings in TotF such as the visuals or AI capability, but that's a side effect of it just being me making the game, and I've tried to price the game appropriately for the level of polish and amount of content I was able to provide. If you do ever feel like giving the game another try, I'd be happy to answer any questions you have about the game or its mechanics if you want to email me at fyiandev@gmail.com. Thanks again!

If you're losing tracking when you punch as hard as you can, it might be because the force of your punch is causing the spring in the battery compartment to compress, causing the battery to lose contact with the other terminal and quickly cut out the power to your controller. Users that have had this problem have reported a variety of fixes to me, like by inserting a stiffer spring, wedging in a conductive shim, putting sticky shelf liner in the battery compartment, or even just putting a small rubber band around the battery to stop it from moving around as easily. If the tracking seems fine, but the punch isn't have the effect you want, try going to the very bottom of the in-game Settings menu and turning off the "Automatic Force Adjustment" checkbox, and then using the two sliders that appear to set your level of strength to whatever feels correct to you. This feature is on by default to allow people to be able to play the game regardless of their level of strength, but it doesn't work very well when you're throwing punches as hard as you possibly can.

Thanks for your review. This is all very fair criticism. It's just me making the game, and so there are some limitations as a result of that, like the focus on room scale only and the basic behavior of the AI (which is also limited in its movement to not tangle up PC players and as a side-effect can be easily locked down). The reason I'm replying, though, is to help out with the punch strength issue you mentioned. There is no specific strength requirement to play TotF. By default, the game looks for your hardest punches and adjusts around those, so if you punch as hard as you can then you'll need to keep punching as hard as you can. The level of strength the game automatically adjusts you to emphasizes swinging at the weak areas marked on the boxing dummy, and they're intentionally a little hard to hit (and directional). My first suggestion is that you throw lighter, throw less, and aim for the weak areas to try to mostly only score high damaging yellow or red shots on the opponent. This might help with the monotonous punching issue you're mentioning and get you moving around your play area more for defensive purposes. If you don't like the automatic strength adjustment, though, you can turn off "Automatic Force Adjustment" at the bottom of the in-game Settings menu and use the two sliders that appear to set your level of strength to whatever feels comfortable. Developer ResponseNov 1 at 10:23 AM

Thanks for your review. The play space requirement is there to help avoid the "slugfest" problem you're mentioning. Having a big enough play area to stand outside of the opponents range makes a huge difference to the gameplay, which is why I stress it in the store description even though the game can technically function with smaller play area sizes. If you have real world boxing experience and/or have very fast hands, you may need to slow yourself down to 80% intensity if the Quest's tracking is having a hard time keeping up or is noticeably drifting outward. There is a damage slider - If you mean for you, you can turn off "Automatic Force Adjustment" in the Settings menu and will see sliders appear that will let adjust your power, or you can turn down the opponent's "Chin/Toughness" setting in the customization menu for a similar result. If you mean the opponent, you can turn down their "Power" in the customization menu. Requests for visual damage indicators are why the colored hit splashes were added to the game (blueish hits don't do much, yellowish hits hurt the opponent, and red hits severely hurt the opponent) - note that there isn't an HP bar that you're inflicting damage to and trying to empty to get knockdowns. Instead, you're trying to land individually damaging hits (primarily by targeting weak areas like the temples or side of the jaw and not just through raw strength - turning off the auto-adjust can make raw strength more of a factor) that can even potentially one-hit KO your opponent with your first hit if it lands right.

Thanks for your review! I'm glad you're enjoying TotF, and I love hearing when real boxers "click" with the game. Because the AI is easier to hit than a real trained opponent would be, the game is designed to force you to aim for weak areas to drop opponents instead of just hitting with raw strength. Nailing the side of the chin can even score a one-hit KO with your very first punch in a bout (unless you're on Endurance or Outclassed mode where the opponents are artificially tougher). Since you're a real-world boxer, I'd also recommend you go to the very bottom of the in-game Settings menu and turn off the "Automatic Force Adjustment" setting, and then use the two sliders that appear to adjust your strength. You may need to experiment with the sliders to figure out what feels the best to you, but it should help things feel consistent and maybe more in line with what you're expecting. You'll probably also want to use the "Customization" mode instead of picking one of the pre-set difficulty modes. You can then dial in exactly what you want from your fights. Increasing Chin/Toughness above 100% will make things artificially tougher and require you to wear down the opponent before you start seeing knockdowns, while increasing Power will make the opponent's hits much more deadly and require you to keep a tight defense. Feel free to experiment!

Developer ResponseNov 1 at 12:12 PM

Thanks for your review! As a lone dev with a nonexistent budget, doing varied crowds that perform well on the Quest definitely wasn't my strength! =) However, you should only have three fights with the night gym crowd (Melky, Ugly Joe, and the Reverend). The 5th, 6th, and 7th fights (Lightning Luis, the Spider, and the Artist) should be in a different venue that's not the training gym and has a less visible audience. And then the 8th, 9th, and 10th fights (Duke, Matty, and Moneymaker) should be in a big arena venue. Since the opponents are easier to hit than a real trained boxer would be (especially one that's not limited by VR-friendly AI movement), the damage system focuses more on where you're hitting (emphasizing the weak areas marked on the dummy) rather than pure raw strength. Building up damage will help you get knockdowns more easily, but building up damage is not what determines when you get a knockdown - the exact effect of your individual swings does. Since you have some real world experience and have now spent some time with the game, you may want to go to the very bottom of the in-game Settings menu and turn off the "Automatic Force Adjustment" option and use the sliders that appear to adjust your strength. Only make small adjustments from the values the sliders start at (or try it without actually changing them at all), because even small changes can have a large effect on the feel of the game. Use those sliders to dial in the feel to whatever feels fun and appropriate to you based on your real-world experience - there is no "true" setting since everybody is going to have different body mass and be swinging differently (which is what the auto-adjust tries to make up for).
